problems.title: Eliminate the constants
problems.problem: Eliminate $a, b$ and $c$ from $z = a(x + y) + b(x - y) + abt + c$.
problems.hint: • Differentiate to eliminate $a,b$ and $c$ and get a PDE.
problems.solution:
The given equation is \begin{equation}\label{eq:02Jan2026-1} z = a(x + y) + b(x - y) + abt + c. \end{equation} Differentiate \eqref{eq:02Jan2026-1} partially with respect to $x,y$ and $t$, respectively, to get \begin{align*} \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} & = a + b \\ \frac{\partial z}{\partial y} & = a - b \\ \frac{\partial z}{\partial t} & = ab. \end{align*}
Since, \begin{align*} (a+b)^2 + (a-b)^2 = 4ab \implies \left( \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} \right) ^2+ \left( \frac{\partial z}{\partial y} \right) ^2 = 4\left( \frac{\partial z}{\partial t} \right). \end{align*}

problems.title: Bernoulli differential equation
problems.problem:
Solve the differential equation 
    \[
        (x^3 y^2 + xy) \mathrm{d} x = \mathrm{d} y.
    \]
problems.hint: • This is Bernoulli's equation.
problems.solution:
Re-write the given equation as \begin{equation}\label{eq:09Jan2026-1} \frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = x^3 y^2 + xy \implies \frac{1}{y^2} \frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} - x^3 = \frac{x}{y}. \end{equation} Put \[ v = \frac{1}{y} \implies \frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}x} = -\frac{1}{y^2}\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} . \] Thus, \eqref{eq:09Jan2026-1} reduces to \begin{equation}\label{eq:09Jan2026-2} -\frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}x} - x^3 = xv \implies \frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}x} + xv = - x^3, \end{equation} which is a linear ODE and can be solved by multiplying with an integrating factor.
The integrating factor is \begin{align*} e^{\int x \mathrm{d} x} = e^{x^2 / 2}. \end{align*} Multiplication of the integrating factor to \eqref{eq:09Jan2026-2} gives \begin{align*} & \frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}x} e^{x^2 / 2} + xv e^{x^2 / 2} = - x^3 e^{x^2 / 2} \\ \implies & \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left( v e^{x^2 / 2} \right) = -x^3 e^{x^2 / 2} \\ \implies & v e^{x^2 / 2} = -\int x^3 e^{x^2 / 2} \\ \implies & v e^{x^2 / 2} = - 2e^{x^2 / 2} \left( \frac{x^2}{2} - 1 \right) + c \\ \implies & \frac{1}{y} e^{x^2 / 2} = - 2e^{x^2 / 2} \left( \frac{x^2}{2} - 1 \right) + c \\ \implies & \frac{1}{y} = - 2\left( \frac{x^2}{2} - 1 \right) + c e^{-x^2 / 2} \\ \implies & \frac{1}{y} = (2 - x^2) + c e^{-x^2 / 2} . \end{align*}

problems.title: Population Growth with Rate Proportional to Population
problems.problem: If the population of a country doubles in 50 years, in how many years will it triple under the assumption that the rate of increase is proportional to the number of inhabitants.
problems.hint:
• Let $P(t)$ denote the population at time $t$. Then, $\frac{\mathrm{d}P}{\mathrm{d}t} \propto P$. Translate into a differential equation involving $P(t)$.
  • Solve this differential equation to express $P(t)$, then use the given doubling condition to determine the constant and find when $P(t)$ becomes three times its initial value.
problems.solution:
Let $P(t)$ denote the population at time $t$. Since the rate of increase of the population is proportional to the number of inhabitants, we have \[ \frac{dP}{dt} = kP, \] where $k>0$ is a constant of proportionality.
Separating variables and integrating, \begin{align*} \frac{1}{P}\,dP = k\,dt & \implies \ln P = kt + C \\ & \implies P(t) = Ce^{kt}. \end{align*} Let $P(0)=P_0$, so $C=P_0$ and \[ P(t) = P_0 e^{kt}. \]
We are given that the population doubles in 50 years: \begin{align*} & P(50) = 2P_0 = P_0 e^{50k} \\ \implies & e^{50k} = 2 \implies k = \frac{\ln 2}{50}. \end{align*}
To find the time $t$ when the population triples, we set \[ P(t) = 3P_0 = P_0 e^{kt}. \] This gives \[ e^{kt} = 3 \quad \implies \quad t = \frac{\ln 3}{k} = 50\frac{\ln 3}{\ln 2}. \] Hence, the population will triple in \[ \boxed{50\frac{\ln 3}{\ln 2} \approx 79 \text{ years}.} \]

problems.title: An exact differential equation (3x^2 + 4xy) \mathrm{d} x + (2x^2 + 2y) \mathrm{d} y= 0
problems.problem:
Solve the differential equation
    \[
        (3x^2 + 4xy) \mathrm{d} x + (2x^2 + 2y) \mathrm{d} y= 0.
    \]
problems.hint: • This is an exact differential equation.
problems.solution:
The given differential equation is \begin{equation}\label{eq:23Jan2026-1} (3x^2 + 4xy) \mathrm{d} x + (2x^2 + 2y) \mathrm{d} y= 0. \end{equation} We will first check if the equation \eqref{eq:23Jan2026-1} is exact or not. Let $M = 3x^2 + 4xy$ and $N = 2x^2 + 2y$. Note that \begin{align*} \frac{\partial M}{\partial y} = 4x \text{ and } \frac{\partial N}{\partial x} = 4x. \end{align*} Since $\frac{\partial M}{\partial y} = \frac{\partial N}{\partial x} $ in the full domain, the equation is exact.
As the equation is exact, we must find $F$ such that \begin{align*} & \frac{\partial F(x,y)}{\partial x} = M(x,y) = 3x^2 + 4xy \text{ and } \\ & \frac{\partial F(x,y)}{\partial y} = N(x,y) = 2x^2 + 2y. \end{align*} From the first equation, \begin{align*} F(x,y) & = \int M(x,y) \mathrm{d} x + \phi(y) \\ & = \int (3x^2 + 4xy) \mathrm{d} x + \phi (y) \\ & = x^3 + 2x^2 y + \phi (y). \end{align*} Since \begin{align*} \frac{\partial F(x,y)}{\partial y} = N(x,y) & \implies 2x^2 + \frac{\mathrm{d}\phi (y)}{\mathrm{d}y} = 2x^2 + 2y \\ & \implies \frac{\mathrm{d}\phi (y)}{\mathrm{d}y} = 2y \\ & \implies \phi (y) = \int 2y \mathrm{d} y + c = y^2 + c, \end{align*} where $c$ is an arbitrary constant. Thus, \[ F(x,y) = x^3 + 2x^2 y + y^2 + c. \]
